name: 文學作品導讀（二）
description:
The course introduces students to a wide range of literary genres, from different geographical areas and historical periods. It is meant to develop skills necessary to read, understand, critically analyze, and (hopefully!) enjoy literary texts. We will learn what to look for while reading fiction, non-fiction, poetry, drama, and graphic narratives. We will use techniques of literary analysis, apply literary studies terminology, and demonstrate an ability to move from descriptive observations about literary texts to larger claims about their meaning, context, and significance. We will also cultivate the ability to put our own ideas into writing and into conversation with others.

At the same time, we will also examine the roles literature has played in individuals’ lives and in society, with a focus on the function of literary works in the 20th and 21st centuries. Questions such as Why is literature produced? Why do we read literature? What effects can literary works have on our lives and contemporary society? will provide the larger framework for our discussion.
goals: Learn key terms and concepts generally applied to the evaluation of literature
Hone skills of close reading and critical thinking
Develop curiosity about the world through context-specific analysis of literary works
Improve sensitivity to the English language
syllabus:
**Approaches to Literary Works**

**Spring 2021**

Instructor: Jessie Shao 邵毓娟                  Email: [ycshao@ntnu.edu.tw](mailto:ycshao@ntnu.edu.tw)

Office: Cheng 808                                   Tel: 77491786

**I. Goals:**

The goal of this course is to provide students with a reasonably compact introduction to the study and appreciation of fiction, poetry, and drama. The selected literary works are studied in terms of basic elements such as plot, setting, point of view, theme, style and tone, symbolism and also in terms of critical concepts and approaches so as to enhance students’ ability in critical reading of literature and to heighten their sensibility to appreciate the aesthetic, social, cultural, ethical, and philosophical dimensions of literary expressions.

**II. Required Textbook:**

Kelly J. Mays ed. _The Norton Introduction to Literature._ New York: Norton, 2013. 11th edition.

**V. Requirements:**

1\. Finish each reading assignment in advance of each class meeting.

2\. Punctual attendance is required. Being late or absent with no reasonable excuse will cause the deduction of the term grade.

3\. Attendance and participation are important. Discussing these texts with the instructor and your peers will enhance your understanding of the texts.

4\. Individual Work: 1. Weekly online quiz and oral presentation. 2. Scheduled Exams: Midterm and Term Project.

5\. Group Work: The class will be divided into a number of groups. There are two group presentations scheduled for this semester.

**VI. Grading Policy**: Your grade will be given based on your performance on the following aspects: 1. Attendance and Participation 20%; 2. Scheduled Exam 20%; 3. Online Work 20%; 4. Group Work 25%; 5. Oral Presentation 15%.
